title: (x) Giants - various {gang}
content:
![giants](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516143307im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/34729.jpg)   
   
Anyone have any idea what this might be based on? I'd guess that it's custom, but if you know of something close I'd love to hear it.   
   
Thanks
author: cchs

comments.content: Chris, These sports logo questions come up a lot. We have talked about having an FAQ about them, I think, because these are almost always custom designs. Especially your major professional franchises. The logos are usually designed by the firms hired by the Leagues or the teams, unless they are based on historical team insignias (which were never fonts in the first place). The teams own the rights to these emblems, so duplicating them is almost the riskiest thing to do -- the higher profile your project has, the more likely you will get 'fanmail' from their lawyers. You didn't say why you wanted to know if there was a font like this, but if you love the teams, buy their gear. Play it safe, is my advice.

Mike,   
   
No worries on copyright infringement, I run a design firm and I get it. I'm not looking to create a do-it-yourself Giants jersey. I'm just looking for a jumping off point for a client who likes the look but can't afford to have us hand letter their charity event logotype.   
   
To better phrase the question, I'm looking for a decent script face that recalls some of the idiosyncracies of sports/baseball lettering. I've seen the stuff at Veer and Letterhead Fonts, but they just don't have the quality I'm looking for.   
   
Anyway, thanks for your post.

Chris, have you looked at some of the other Sign font sites like [SignFonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516143307/http:/artandsignstudio.com/fonts.html) and [Sign DNA](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516143307/http:/www.signdna.com/v2/index.php). My impression is that these are less well-known, but might have some qualities you are after.

Christopher,   
 [Monotype Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516143307/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/monotype-script/) (or Script MT, as my copy is named) will yield this:   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516143307im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/34751.gif)   
   
A quick modification of the G's beard and the crossbar on the t and   
you've got a similar look ... kinda, sorta?

You can also take a look at [BrewMaster Modern](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516143307/http:/www.fontmesa.com/font_index_page2.htm) for the lowercase.   
 [Spills](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516143307/http:/www2.comicbookfonts.com/e/env/0001z4M6IUbE4ysovI8n0B8/search.html?link=/fonts/DL/catalog.html&item=fonts:dl205), although it's not so "regular" has a similar G.   
 [Fabulous](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516143307/http:/houseind.com/house.php?kit=VEGAS-FO&sub=view) could be in the style too.

You could look at CG Coronet too.   
   
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/coronet-rr/bold/testdrive.html?s=Giants&p=72](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516143307/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/coronet-rr/bold/testdrive.html?s=Giants&p=72)
Hey thanks! I'm a book designer so it seemed appropriately... bookish.
I second the PF logo appreciation. Very classy, Patricia!
Aw shucks... you guys are the best.
